elements.content: Direct control over structure and location of catalytic species deposited on amorphous supports represents a formidable challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In contrast, a structurally well-defined, crystalline metal–organic framework (MOF) can be rationally designed using postsynthetic techniques to allow for desired structural or locational changes of deposited metal ions. Herein, naphthalene dicarboxylate linkers are incorporated in the MOF, NU-1000, to block the small cavities where few-atom clusters of cobalt oxide preferentially grow, inducing catalyst deposition toward hitherto ill-favored grafting sites orientated toward NU-1000s mesoporous channels. Despite the different cobalt oxide location, the resulting material is still an active propane oxidative dehydrogenation catalyst at low temperature, reaching a turnover frequency of 0.68 ± 0.05 h–1 at 230 °C and confirming the utility of MOFs as crystalline supports to guide rational design of catalysts.
elements.clean_text: Direct control over structure and location of catalytic species deposited on amorphous supports represents a formidable challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In contrast, a structurally well-defined, crystalline metal-organic framework (MOF) can be rationally designed using postsynthetic techniques to allow for desired structural or locational changes of deposited metal ions. Herein, naphthalene dicarboxylate linkers are incorporated in the MOF, NU-1000, to block the small cavities where few-atom clusters of cobalt oxide preferentially grow, inducing catalyst deposition toward hitherto ill-favored grafting sites orientated toward NU-1000s mesoporous channels. Despite the different cobalt oxide location, the resulting material is still an active propane oxidative dehydrogenation catalyst at low temperature, reaching a turnover frequency of 0.68 ± 0.05 h-1 at 230 °C and confirming the utility of MOFs as crystalline supports to guide rational design of catalysts.

elements.content: Deposition of catalytically active metal ions/clusters on high surface area supports, traditionally conducted through routes including impregnation, precipitation, and vapor-phase deposition, can lead to improved activities and enhanced stabilities, due to increased dispersion, preferential exposure of active sites, and strong metal–support interactions. These properties, often merged under the umbrella term of “support effects”, are obfuscated by the broad distribution of grafting sites present on amorphous supports, frequently leading to a lack of intimate knowledge of the nature of the deposited catalysts, especially in systems where the catalyst structure undergoes dynamic changes during operation. Nonuniformity of the active sites in these ill-defined catalysts generally complicates the unearthing of structure–function relationships, thereby inhibiting rational design of new and improved materials for a given catalytic reaction. Moreover, surface engineering of these materials, in order to engender enhanced reactivity, likewise yields abstruse results in which changes in catalytic activity may not necessarily correlate to prognosticative changes in structure. For example, the catalytic activity/stability of zeolites with Brønsted acidic sites (where a fraction of Si4+ ions have been exchanged with Al3+ ions and a corresponding charge-balancing H+) can be tuned based on the deprotonation energy associated with isolated vs paired Al3+ ions sited in a given multi–membered ring. Although the location of these acidic Al3+ sites can be altered slightly with the inclusion of various organic cations, these methods can fall short on predictable trends, making new catalyst discovery largely a trial and error process.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Deposition of catalytically active metal ions/clusters on high surface area supports, traditionally conducted through routes including impregnation, precipitation, and vapor-phase deposition, can lead to improved activities and enhanced stabilities, due to increased dispersion, preferential exposure of active sites, and strong metal-support interactions. These properties, often merged under the umbrella term of "support effects", are obfuscated by the broad distribution of grafting sites present on amorphous supports, frequently leading to a lack of intimate knowledge of the nature of the deposited catalysts, especially in systems where the catalyst structure undergoes dynamic changes during operation. Nonuniformity of the active sites in these ill-defined catalysts generally complicates the unearthing of structure-function relationships, thereby inhibiting rational design of new and improved materials for a given catalytic reaction. Moreover, surface engineering of these materials, in order to engender enhanced reactivity, likewise yields abstruse results in which changes in catalytic activity may not necessarily correlate to prognosticative changes in structure. For example, the catalytic activity/stability of zeolites with Brønsted acidic sites (where a fraction of Si4+ ions have been exchanged with Al3+ ions and a corresponding charge-balancing H+) can be tuned based on the deprotonation energy associated with isolated vs paired Al3+ ions sited in a given multi-membered ring. Although the location of these acidic Al3+ sites can be altered slightly with the inclusion of various organic cations, these methods can fall short on predictable trends, making new catalyst discovery largely a trial and error process.

elements.content: To circumvent the challenges of structural characterization on amorphous supports, our group and others have begun using metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), crystalline materials composed of inorganic nodes coordinated via multitopic linkers, as catalytic supports in an attempt to obtain atomically precise active sites for establishing rigorous structure/function relationships. The hydroxo/aqua ligands often present on MOF nodes are tantalizing grafting sites due to their crystallographically defined and site-isolated nature, facilitating structural characterization of deposited catalysts. In particular, the MOF NU-1000, with its Zr6(μ3–OH)4(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)4 nodes and tetratopic pyrene-based linkers, has been used as a catalyst support for alkane oxidative dehydrogenation, alkane oxidation, alkene hydrogenation, and oligomerization reactions to name a few. Because of the 8-connected Zr6 nodes, NU-1000 has hydroxide/aqua ligands orientated toward both wide 3 nm hexagonal pores as well as in smaller 8 Å cavities along the c-axis of the MOF. Curiously, preferential adsorption and subsequent deposition of a variety of metal precursors occurs in the small cavities within the MOF and has been ascribed to greater London dispersion interactions between the metal precursors and the MOF support at these sites (). We note this predilection appears to be observed among other MOF-based materials where preferential binding of metal precursors occurs in spatially confined areas despite availability of binding sites in less sterically demanding positions. Furthermore, due to the close proximity of the two nodes along the c-axis in NU-1000, metal ions have the opportunity to form few-atom clusters bridging between the two adjacent nodes, making structural characterization of the deposited material exponentially more challenging. To inhibit cluster growth in this confined space, and to direct the deposition of metal ions toward the wide mesoporous hexagonal channels, we hypothesized that the installation of an organic linker occupying the small cavities prior to the metal-anchoring process could effectively prevent metal ion agglomeration at this site. Given the literature precedence of postsynthetically installing new linkers (additional linkers) to engineer MOFs with new topologies, we set out to install a dicarboxylate linker via a well-established technique, solvent-assisted ligand incorporation (SALI). With the overarching goal of synthesizing site-isolated catalysts, the results presented herein highlight how the tunability of MOFs can yield a material where deliberate manipulation of the support framework predictively changes the catalyst structure.
elements.clean_text: To circumvent the challenges of structural characterization on amorphous supports, our group and others have begun using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), crystalline materials composed of inorganic nodes coordinated via multitopic linkers, as catalytic supports in an attempt to obtain atomically precise active sites for establishing rigorous structure/function relationships. The hydroxo/aqua ligands often present on MOF nodes are tantalizing grafting sites due to their crystallographically defined and site-isolated nature, facilitating structural characterization of deposited catalysts. In particular, the MOF NU-1000, with its Zr6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O)4(OH)4(H2O)4 nodes and tetratopic pyrene-based linkers, has been used as a catalyst support for alkane oxidative dehydrogenation, alkane oxidation, alkene hydrogenation, and oligomerization reactions to name a few. Because of the 8-connected Zr6 nodes, NU-1000 has hydroxide/aqua ligands orientated toward both wide 3 nm hexagonal pores as well as in smaller 8 Å cavities along the c-axis of the MOF. Curiously, preferential adsorption and subsequent deposition of a variety of metal precursors occurs in the small cavities within the MOF and has been ascribed to greater London dispersion interactions between the metal precursors and the MOF support at these sites (). We note this predilection appears to be observed among other MOF-based materials where preferential binding of metal precursors occurs in spatially confined areas despite availability of binding sites in less sterically demanding positions. Furthermore, due to the close proximity of the two nodes along the c-axis in NU-1000, metal ions have the opportunity to form few-atom clusters bridging between the two adjacent nodes, making structural characterization of the deposited material exponentially more challenging. To inhibit cluster growth in this confined space, and to direct the deposition of metal ions toward the wide mesoporous hexagonal channels, we hypothesized that the installation of an organic linker occupying the small cavities prior to the metal-anchoring process could effectively prevent metal ion agglomeration at this site. Given the literature precedence of postsynthetically installing new linkers (additional linkers) to engineer MOFs with new topologies, we set out to install a dicarboxylate linker via a well-established technique, solvent-assisted ligand incorporation (SALI). elements.content: Structure of NU-1000 with emphasis on observed electron density of metal ions after postsynthetic anchoring of metal sites (Zr, green spheres; O, red spheres; C, gray). In the absence of NDC (see following text), deposition occurs near exclusively in the 8 Å cavities of NU-1000 (blue mesh) rather than on hydroxides/aqua ligands pointed toward the 30 Å mesopores (purple mesh).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of NU-1000 with emphasis on observed electron density of metal ions after postsynthetic anchoring of metal sites (Zr, green spheres; O, red spheres; C, gray). In the absence of NDC (see following text), deposition occurs near exclusively in the 8 Å cavities of NU-1000 (blue mesh) rather than on hydroxides/aqua ligands pointed toward the 30 Å mesopores (purple mesh).

elements.content: Naphthalenedicarboxylate acid (79 mg, 0.37 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) in an 8-dram vial with sonication. NU-1000 (200 mg, 0.091 mmol, see the for synthetic details) was added to the solution and heated overnight (16 h) at 65 °C. The resultant material was washed with hot DMF four times over 8 h. The material (NDC-SALI) was then transferred to a 100 mL screw-top jar with 48 mL of DMF. Then, 2 mL of aqueous 8 M HCl was added and the jar was placed into a 100 °C oven overnight. The material was then washed with DMF over the course of 8 h (4 × 40 mL) and then solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL) before thermally activating the material at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum to yield NDC-SALI-HCl.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

NDC-SALI

Naphthalenedicarboxylate acid (79 mg, 0.37 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) in an 8-dram vial with sonication. NU-1000 (200 mg, 0.091 mmol, see the  for synthetic details) was added to the solution and heated overnight (16 h) at 65 °C. The resultant material was washed with hot DMF four times over 8 h. The material (NDC-SALI) was then transferred to a 100 mL screw-top jar with 48 mL of DMF. Then, 2 mL of aqueous 8 M HCl was added and the jar was placed into a 100 °C oven overnight. The material was then washed with DMF over the course of 8 h (4 × 40 mL) and then solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL) before thermally activating the material at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum to yield NDC-SALI-HCl.

elements.content: Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (125 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 18.7 mL of DMF with sonication. Subsequently, NDC-SALI-HCl (150 mg, 0.063 mmol) was added to the solution and placed in a 100 °C oven for 16 h. The material was centrifuged and washed with hot DMF (4 × 40 mL) before being solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL). The material (Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) was then thermally treated at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Co-SIM-NDC-SALI

Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (125 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 18.7 mL of DMF with sonication. Subsequently, NDC-SALI-HCl (150 mg, 0.063 mmol) was added to the solution and placed in a 100 °C oven for 16 h. The material was centrifuged and washed with hot DMF (4 × 40 mL) before being solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL). The material (Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) was then thermally treated at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum.

elements.content: The catalyst (∼35 mg Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, diluted with ∼350 mg of high-purity, low-surface-area SiO2) was packed on quartz wool in a stainless steel reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled with a K-type thermocouple sited above the catalyst bed. For the catalyst pretreatment procedure, the temperature was ramped at 10 °C/min to 180 °C and then 2 °C/min to a final temperature of 230 °C under a flow of 48 mL/min O2 (10%, diluted with He) and 96 mL/min of C3H8 (3%, diluted with Ar) (0.5 bar pressure) for 4 h. For the catalysis, the ratio of flow rates between the two reacting gases is kept constant for all the experiments, in which the ratio of C3H8:O2 was 6:5. The rates used in the TOF plots were recorded in the differential conversion regime (<10% conversion).
elements.clean_text:
Gas-Phase Catalysis

The catalyst (~35 mg Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, diluted with ~350 mg of high-purity, low-surface-area SiO2) was packed on quartz wool in a stainless steel reactor. The reaction temperature was controlled with a K-type thermocouple sited above the catalyst bed. For the catalyst pretreatment procedure, the temperature was ramped at 10 °C/min to 180 °C and then 2 °C/min to a final temperature of 230 °C under a flow of 48 mL/min O2 (10%, diluted with He) and 96 mL/min of C3H8 (3%, diluted with Ar) (0.5 bar pressure) for 4 h. For the catalysis, the ratio of flow rates between the two reacting gases is kept constant for all the experiments, in which the ratio of C3H8:O2 was 6:5. The rates used in the TOF plots were recorded in the differential conversion regime (<10% conversion).

elements.content: The node-to-node distance along the c-axis in NU-1000 (the space in which postsynthetically anchored metal ions reside) is approximately 8.5 Å. We hypothesized that 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (NDC, oxygen-to-oxygen distance of ∼9 Å) could bridge between two adjacent nodes, akin to the SALI process (). Reliant on exchange of labile aqua/hydroxo ligands with carboxylates/phosphonates, SALI is an effective method of installing new structural or functional groups on MOF nodes. Soaking NU-1000 in solutions of NDC with varying concentrations and equivalents results in an NDC incorporation ranging from 1–2.6 NDC linkers per node of NU-1000 (NDC-SALI, ) as determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy following digestion of the material in a D2SO4/DMSO solution (). Although not surprising, because the node of NU-1000 allows for up to four additional monotopically bound carboxylates, loadings above one NDC per node are nonideal as ligands that do not bridge between nodes occupy sites that otherwise would be used to graft catalyst ions.
elements.clean_text:
Results & Discussion

The node-to-node distance along the c-axis in NU-1000 (the space in which postsynthetically anchored metal ions reside) is approximately 8.5 Å. We hypothesized that 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (NDC, oxygen-to-oxygen distance of ~9 Å) could bridge between two adjacent nodes, akin to the SALI process (). Reliant on exchange of labile aqua/hydroxo ligands with carboxylates/phosphonates, SALI is an effective method of installing new structural or functional groups on MOF nodes. Soaking NU-1000 in solutions of NDC with varying concentrations and equivalents results in an NDC incorporation ranging from 1-2.6 NDC linkers per node of NU-1000 (NDC-SALI, ) as determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy following digestion of the material in a D2SO4/DMSO solution (). Although not surprising, because the node of NU-1000 allows for up to four additional monotopically bound carboxylates, loadings above one NDC per node are nonideal as ligands that do not bridge between nodes occupy sites that otherwise would be used to graft catalyst ions.

elements.content: Reaction scheme depicting the possible locations of a ditopic linker such as NDC in NU-1000. Upon an HCl wash, monotopic linkers should be cleaved from the structure. Zr node in green, pyrene linker in purple, NDC ligand in magenta.
elements.clean_text: 2  Reaction scheme depicting the possible locations of a ditopic linker such as NDC in NU-1000. Upon an HCl wash, monotopic linkers should be cleaved from the structure. Zr node in green, pyrene linker in purple, NDC ligand in magenta.

elements.content: To remove monotopically bound NDC ligands, we soaked the material in an HCl/DMF solution (a solution that also removes monotopic benzoate ligands from the parent material) to replace these linkers with −OH/OH2 groups, reasoning that ditopically bound linkers bridging between the nodes would persist because of the chelating effect. Under optimized conditions (), mild acid activation satisfyingly removes all but one NDC molecule per node (material hereafter named NDC-SALI-HCl, ), suggesting the presence of only a bridging motif for the NDC ligand. Infrared spectroscopy () confirmed the presence of free carboxylic acids in NDC-SALI and their removal upon the HCl treatment, i.e., peaks at 3575 and 1700–1746 cm–1 in the IR spectrum of NDC-SALI attributed to the free carboxylic acid groups on an NDC ligand disappear after the HCl wash process. Additionally, the mesoporous step in the N2 sorption isotherm of NDC-SALI (2.63 NDC/Zr6 node) occurs at slightly slower pressure than for NU-1000, consistent with partial occupation of the mesopore of the former with NDC ligands. Again, after the HCl wash, the surface area and pore size of the MOF are nearly restored to the parent MOF’s properties (), consistent with removal of NDC ligands from the mesoporous channel.
elements.clean_text: To remove monotopically bound NDC ligands, we soaked the material in an HCl/DMF solution (a solution that also removes monotopic benzoate ligands from the parent material) to replace these linkers with -OH/OH2 groups, reasoning that ditopically bound linkers bridging between the nodes would persist because of the chelating effect. Under optimized conditions (), mild acid activation satisfyingly removes all but one NDC molecule per node (material hereafter named NDC-SALI-HCl, ), suggesting the presence of only a bridging motif for the NDC ligand. Infrared spectroscopy () confirmed the presence of free carboxylic acids in NDC-SALI and their removal upon the HCl treatment, i.e., peaks at 3575 and 1700-1746 cm-1 in the IR spectrum of NDC-SALI attributed to the free carboxylic acid groups on an NDC ligand disappear after the HCl wash process. Additionally, the mesoporous step in the N2 sorption isotherm of NDC-SALI (2.63 NDC/Zr6 node) occurs at slightly slower pressure than for NU-1000, consistent with partial occupation of the mesopore of the former with NDC ligands. Again, after the HCl wash, the surface area and pore size of the MOF are nearly restored to the parent MOF's properties (), consistent with removal of NDC ligands from the mesoporous channel.

elements.content: To confirm the location and binding motif of the NDC ligand, we conducted the SALI of NDC and subsequent acid wash process using NU-1000 crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. As displayed in , the NDC ligands are sited between pairs Zr6 nodes along the c-axis, resulting in 10-connected Zr6 nodes (, ). To accommodate the slightly greater length of the NDC ligand compared to that of the cavity, the unit cell of NDC-SALI-HCl expands in the c-dimension from 16.4829(3) to 16.835(2) Å. Inferred from the observed disorder, the NDC ligand also adopts one of two orientations (site occupancy of 50% each) that are superimposed in the crystal structure, presumably to reduce strain from the slight nonlinearity of the ligandan arrangement also observed in DUT-52, a 12-connected MOF with NDC linkers.
elements.clean_text: To confirm the location and binding motif of the NDC ligand, we conducted the SALI of NDC and subsequent acid wash process using NU-1000 crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. As displayed in , the NDC ligands are sited between pairs Zr6 nodes along the c-axis, resulting in 10-connected Zr6 nodes (, ). To accommodate the slightly greater length of the NDC ligand compared to that of the cavity, the unit cell of NDC-SALI-HCl expands in the c-dimension from 16.4829(3) to 16.835(2) Å. Inferred from the observed disorder, the NDC ligand also adopts one of two orientations (site occupancy of 50% each) that are superimposed in the crystal structure, presumably to reduce strain from the slight nonlinearity of the ligandan arrangement also observed in DUT-52, a 12-connected MOF with NDC linkers.

elements.content: Structure of NDC-SALI-HCl derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. The two orientations of the NDC ligand are shown in blue and magenta for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of NDC-SALI-HCl derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. The two orientations of the NDC ligand are shown in blue and magenta for clarity.

elements.content: With NDC-SALI-HCl in hand and confirmation of the location of NDC within the crystal structure, we sought to deposit cobalt ions onto the node of NU-1000 using a previously developed method, solvothermal deposition in MOFs (SIM). In short, NDC-SALI-HCl was soaked in a heated solution containing cobalt acetate in order to metalate the node (see the for details). After extensive washing, a blue material (hereafter named Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) was obtained that contained 3.3 ± 0.5 Co ions per Zr6 node uniformly throughout the crystallite as determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy and line scans derived from energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (), respectively, while retaining the parent material’s porosity and crystallinity (). Curiously, the material visibly differs from the NDC-free version of Co-SIM-treated NU-1000, the latter being a green powder. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy () of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI corroborates these observations, revealing slightly different absorption spectra for the two materials. Both exhibit a trio of peaks (519, 580, and 747 nm for Co-SIM and 536, 584, and 615 nm for Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) attributable to Co2+ in a tetrahedral environment (). Co-SIM additionally has increased absorption at 730 nm, possibly indicating presence of octahedral Co2+ that may arise due to coordination of atmospheric water to the metal ion. No leaching of NDC linkers was observed after metalation, encouraging us to use differential envelope density (DED) analyses to locate the newly anchored Co-oxo species. A DED analysis relies on the electron envelopes generated from high intensity, low-angle diffraction peaks using synchrotron X-ray sources. By subtracting the electron envelope generated from the parent material as the background, the additional electron density map corresponding to the newly anchored species can be obtained, affording a reliable technique to obtain their location information. DEDs of NDC-SALI-HCl and Co-SIM-NDC-SALI were analyzed to locate the NDC ligands and Co ions, respectively (). Electron density from the NDC ligands in NDC-SALI-HCl is observed exclusively between the nodes along the c-axis, aligning well with the single crystal X-ray diffraction structure. In Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, electron density attributed to the cobalt is observed pointing toward the mesopores on the Zr6 nodes, in striking contrast to Co-SIM where the Co is predominantly located in the space now occupied by NDC linker.

In short, NDC-SALI-HCl was soaked in a heated solution containing cobalt acetate in order to metalate the node (see the  for details). Diffuse reflectance UV-vis spectroscopy () of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI corroborates these observations, revealing slightly different absorption spectra for the two materials. Both exhibit a trio of peaks (519, 580, and 747 nm for Co-SIM and 536, 584, and 615 nm for Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) attributable to Co2+ in a tetrahedral environment (). Co-SIM additionally has increased absorption at 730 nm, possibly indicating presence of octahedral Co2+ that may arise due to coordination of atmospheric water to the metal ion. A DED analysis relies on the electron envelopes generated from high intensity, low-angle diffraction peaks using synchrotron X-ray sources. By subtracting the electron envelope generated from the parent material as the background, the additional electron density map corresponding to the newly anchored species can be obtained, affording a reliable technique to obtain their location information. DEDs of NDC-SALI-HCl and Co-SIM-NDC-SALI were analyzed to locate the NDC ligands and Co ions, respectively (). Electron density from the NDC ligands in NDC-SALI-HCl is observed exclusively between the nodes along the c-axis, aligning well with the single crystal X-ray diffraction structure. In Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, electron density attributed to the cobalt is observed pointing toward the mesopores on the Zr6 nodes, in striking contrast to Co-SIM where the Co is predominantly located in the space now occupied by NDC linker.

elements.content: DED maps of (a) NDC-SALI-HCl along the a-axis, and (b) Co-SIM-NDC-SALI viewed along the MOF crystallographic c-axis, and (c) a-axis. Electron density taken from the subtraction of NU-1000 from NDC-SALI-HCl is shown in magenta. Electron density envelopes attributed to Co2+ ions are shown in blue and taken from the subtraction of NDC-SALI-HCl from Co-SIM-NDC-SALI.
elements.clean_text: 4  DED maps of (a) NDC-SALI-HCl along the a-axis, and (b) Co-SIM-NDC-SALI viewed along the MOF crystallographic c-axis, and (c) a-axis. Electron density taken from the subtraction of NU-1000 from NDC-SALI-HCl is shown in magenta. Electron density envelopes attributed to Co2+ ions are shown in blue and taken from the subtraction of NDC-SALI-HCl from Co-SIM-NDC-SALI.

elements.content: Inspired by our previous work, where subtle changes in the local Co coordination environment produced markedly different catalytic materials in the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane (a), we aimed to determine if catalytic activity of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI was retained after migration of the cobalt sites to the mesopores. A plug-flow reactor was used to test the catalytic activity of the material in the presence of oxygen and propane at high temperatures. After an activation period in which oxygen and propane flowed over the catalyst at 230 °C (C3H8:O2 6:5), the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by plotting the propane conversion (to propylene and the overoxidized product, CO2) as a function of the propane molar space time (W/F, b). The TOFs measured using these conditions were determined to be 0.68 ± 0.05 and 0.10 ± 0.01 h–1 at 230 and 215 °C, respectively. Under identical reaction conditions at 230 °C Co-SIM has a TOF of 0.54 ± 0.12 h–1. A plot of the product distribution against conversion (c) shows a steep decrease in propylene selectivity above modest conversions, similar to that of Co-SIM. Therefore, we infer that CO2 generation arises from the more easily oxidized propylene product with minimal direct propane combustion (r 2 ≈ 0). Postcatalysis characterization () confirms that the bulk properties of the catalyst do not differ much from the as-prepared material, confirming that the location of the cobalt does not affect the stability of the catalyst.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by our previous work, where subtle changes in the local Co coordination environment produced markedly different catalytic materials in the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane (a), we aimed to determine if catalytic activity of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI was retained after migration of the cobalt sites to the mesopores. A plug-flow reactor was used to test the catalytic activity of the material in the presence of oxygen and propane at high temperatures. After an activation period in which oxygen and propane flowed over the catalyst at 230 °C (C3H8:O2 6:5), the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by plotting the propane conversion (to propylene and the overoxidized product, CO2) as a function of the propane molar space time (W/F, b). The TOFs measured using these conditions were determined to be 0.68 ± 0.05 and 0.10 ± 0.01 h-1 at 230 and 215 °C, respectively. Under identical reaction conditions at 230 °C Co-SIM has a TOF of 0.54 ± 0.12 h-1. A plot of the product distribution against conversion (c) shows a steep decrease in propylene selectivity above modest conversions, similar to that of Co-SIM. Therefore, we infer that CO2 generation arises from the more easily oxidized propylene product with minimal direct propane combustion (r 2 ~ 0). Postcatalysis characterization () confirms that the bulk properties of the catalyst do not differ much from the as-prepared material, confirming that the location of the cobalt does not affect the stability of the catalyst.

elements.content: Summary of the catalytic activity of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI. (a) Reaction scheme of oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. (b) TOF determination at 230 and 215 °C. (c) Propene selectivity at different propane conversion levels.
elements.clean_text: 5  Summary of the catalytic activity of Co-SIM-NDC-SALI. (a) Reaction scheme of oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. (b) TOF determination at 230 and 215 °C. (c) Propene selectivity at different propane conversion levels.

elements.content: Herein, we described a method to redirect catalyst deposition to different sites in a well-ordered support. NDC ligands were used to effectively bridge between two adjacent nodes in NU-1000 inducing cobalt ions to coordinate in previously unfavorable sites. Although only a small reactivity difference is observed between the Co-SIM and Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, we note that this strategy can be applied to areas where catalyst location is imperative in order to engender unique reactivity. Examples where, for instance, proximal Lewis acids/bases aid in stabilizing bound intermediates are common. We imagine that being able to predict and manipulate catalyst deposition in three-dimensional space will greatly aid in the rational design of improved catalysts. In this particular case, circumventing the preference for concentrated, intranode siting greatly facilitates structural identification of deposited catalysts, as multiatom clusters that bridge between the nodes are significantly more difficult to characterize than sets of one or two ions that are sited on single faces of a Zr6 node. This type of catalyst manipulation and characterization would be difficult to achieve with traditional supports and validates MOFs as a useful structural backbone for catalyst organization.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Herein, we described a method to redirect catalyst deposition to different sites in a well-ordered support. NDC ligands were used to effectively bridge between two adjacent nodes in NU-1000 inducing cobalt ions to coordinate in previously unfavorable sites. Although only a small reactivity difference is observed between the Co-SIM and Co-SIM-NDC-SALI, we note that this strategy can be applied to areas where catalyst location is imperative in order to engender unique reactivity. Examples where, for instance, proximal Lewis acids/bases aid in stabilizing bound intermediates are common. We imagine that being able to predict and manipulate catalyst deposition in three-dimensional space will greatly aid in the rational design of improved catalysts. In this particular case, circumventing the preference for concentrated, intranode siting greatly facilitates structural identification of deposited catalysts, as multiatom clusters that bridge between the nodes are significantly more difficult to characterize than sets of one or two ions that are sited on single faces of a Zr6 node. This type of catalyst manipulation and characterization would be difficult to achieve with traditional supports and validates MOFs as a useful structural backbone for catalyst organization.

cln_elements.content: Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (125 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 18.7 mL of DMF with sonication. Subsequently, NDC-SALI-HCl (150 mg, 0.063 mmol) was added to the solution and placed in a 100 °C oven for 16 h. The material was centrifuged and washed with hot DMF (4 × 40 mL) before being solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL). The material (Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) was then thermally treated at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Co-SIM-NDC-SALI

Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (125 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 18.7 mL of DMF with sonication. Subsequently, NDC-SALI-HCl (150 mg, 0.063 mmol) was added to the solution and placed in a 100 °C oven for 16 h. The material was centrifuged and washed with hot DMF (4 × 40 mL) before being solvent exchanged to acetone (4 × 40 mL). The material (Co-SIM-NDC-SALI) was then thermally treated at 100 °C for 16 h under dynamic vacuum.

cln_elements.content: Structure of NU-1000 with emphasis on observed electron density of metal ions after postsynthetic anchoring of metal sites (Zr, green spheres; O, red spheres; C, gray). In the absence of NDC (see following text), deposition occurs near exclusively in the 8 Å cavities of NU-1000 (blue mesh) rather than on hydroxides/aqua ligands pointed toward the 30 Å mesopores (purple mesh).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of NU-1000 with emphasis on observed electron density of metal ions after postsynthetic anchoring of metal sites (Zr, green spheres; O, red spheres; C, gray). In the absence of NDC (see following text), deposition occurs near exclusively in the 8 Å cavities of NU-1000 (blue mesh) rather than on hydroxides/aqua ligands pointed toward the 30 Å mesopores (purple mesh).

cln_elements.content: Reaction scheme depicting the possible locations of a ditopic linker such as NDC in NU-1000. Upon an HCl wash, monotopic linkers should be cleaved from the structure. Zr node in green, pyrene linker in purple, NDC ligand in magenta.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Reaction scheme depicting the possible locations of a ditopic linker such as NDC in NU-1000. Upon an HCl wash, monotopic linkers should be cleaved from the structure. Zr node in green, pyrene linker in purple, NDC ligand in magenta.

cln_elements.content: Structure of NDC-SALI-HCl derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. The two orientations of the NDC ligand are shown in blue and magenta for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of NDC-SALI-HCl derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. The two orientations of the NDC ligand are shown in blue and magenta for clarity.

cln_elements.content: DED maps of (a) NDC-SALI-HCl along the a-axis, and (b) Co-SIM-NDC-SALI viewed along the MOF crystallographic c-axis, and (c) a-axis. Electron density taken from the subtraction of NU-1000 from NDC-SALI-HCl is shown in magenta. Electron density envelopes attributed to Co2+ ions are shown in blue and taken from the subtraction of NDC-SALI-HCl from Co-SIM-NDC-SALI.

Electron density envelopes attributed to Co2+ ions are shown in blue and taken from the subtraction of NDC-SALI-HCl from Co-SIM-NDC-SALI.
